content.question: <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>A</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> above represent pieces of the same conducting material but of different dimensions that behave as resistors when connected in circuits. Conductor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>A</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and a square cross section with sides of length <math alttext="s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Conductor <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has length <math alttext="2 L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and a square cross section with sides of length <math alttext="2 s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. When the potential differences across conductors <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>A</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="3 V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively, as shown above, the current through <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>A</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="I sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the current through <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
